moves.1. c4:
When I have spoken to people and asked, given the choice what would you prefer to trade? An active knight for a strong bishop, or vice versa? The majority usually opt to trade the knight for an opponents bishop I would say, in my experience. However this game serves as an example of just how lethal a pair of active knights really can be.
      The English, I like this opening myself, which means I also know how it works...
moves.1... e5: I stake my claim on the center, white cannot be given time to consolidate a strong center himself..
moves.2... Bc5: Some people don't like this move, I still use it though I often get good results when I do, maybe not strictly because of this move though....
moves.3. g3: e3 is often the response, I like that it's not....
moves.3... Nf6: Because I don't have to spend time moving my bishop around yet..
moves.4... d6: I decide I'm happy to trade bishop for knight at this point if it came down to it...
moves.5. Bg2 c6: Defending againt Nb5/d5 or a sneaky + on a4...
moves.7... O-O 8. b3: Allowing the d-pawn to continue it's march and possible suicide on d4...
moves.9. O-O Bh3: A common but effective tactic to annihilate the defending bishop...
moves.10... Na6: Not the usual way of developing a knight but I felt c7 was a good route for it to take to enter battle..
moves.11. a3: These pawn pushes are giving me time to swing my Q's knight over towards the white king....
moves.11... Bxg2: As he didn't play Bh1 I don't give a second chance for a change of heart...
moves.12. Kxg2 Nc7 13. Na4: Now I'm in the position where I can't save the loss of both bishops....
moves.13... Ne6: So I press on galloping my horses into battle...
moves.14. Bb2: Now I have to decide if I want to move that Bishop and save a pawn...
moves.14... Ng5: The Attack seemed more critical than the defence of a pawn, I didn't want to be slowed down or distracted by minor issue's, knowing full well just how often games are decided by such "minor" issue's...
moves.15. Ng1: Defending against Qh3+ and a nice little attack....
moves.15... Bb6: I can save the pawn now, I don't wanna give it away for nothing...
moves.16. Qc2 h5: I wanted to send in a battering ram if poss, also it serves as an outpost for g4 for a minute....
moves.17. Nxb6 axb6: The Bishop wasn't playing a leading role in the game so I was content for it to perish...
moves.18. f4: This move caused me to take stock, I couldn't take with the e pawn b'cus the exchange on f6 would rip open my kings defences and expose him to the harsh realities that no king need endure, So...
moves.19. fxe5 dxe5 20. Bxe5 Ng4: I had forseen this sequence and I liked how it looked...The white king is exposed to the elements and both my knights are within striking distance...
moves.21. Bb2: Back to safety, but also out of the way....
moves.21... Rfe8: Threatening to even up the score...
moves.22. Qc3: White makes a threat of his own, a deadly one!
moves.23. d4: This move allows a beautiful ending to the game leaving white helpless...
moves.24... Qf5: While I seek to end it permanently..
moves.25. Ref1: Re2 might have been a better defence....
moves.26... Nf2+: I could have been greedy and slaughtered a rook here for free but this seemed the best move to me, far more elegant. As a consequence my opponent resigned, there is no defence 27.Rxf2 Qxf2 and white cannot defend against mate on g2 next move. A nice example of knight dominance I thought. Thx and comments are always welcome.

gameName: My Kingdom for a horse Q.A.com
